review.title: EEG-Based User Reaction Time Estimation Using Riemannian Geometry Features
review.abstract: Riemannian geometry has been successfully used in many brain-computer interface (BCI) classification problems and demonstrated superior performance. In this paper, for the first time, it is applied to BCI regression problems, an important category of BCI applications. More specifically, we propose a new feature extraction approach for Electroencephalogram (EEG) based BCI regression problems: a spatial filter is first used to increase the signal quality of the EEG trials and also to reduce the dimensionality of the covariance matrices, and then Riemannian tangent space features are extracted. We validate the performance of the proposed approach in reaction time estimation from EEG signals measured in a large-scale sustained-attention psychomotor vigilance task, and show that compared with the traditional powerband features, the tangent space features can reduce the root mean square estimation error by 4.30-8.30%, and increase the estimation correlation coefficient by 6.59-11.13%.

sections.heading: D. RT versus Fatigue State
sections.text: We also investigated the relationship between the RT and the fatigue state. Our assumption is that the RT should be greater as the level of fatigue increases. RT box plots in different sessions for two typical subjects are shown in Fig. 11, where "L," "N" and "H" respectively mean low, normal and high fatigue. Fig. 11 shows that the mean RT of a session with high fatigue is generally greater than that of a session with low or normal fatigue, and the former also has more extreme values and greater variance. The difference between a session with low fatigue and a session with normal fatigue is not obvious.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE RESEARCH
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a new approach to feature extraction for EEG-based BCI regression problems: First, a spatial filter is used to increase the quality of the EEG test signal and also to decrease the dimensionality of the covariance matrix, and then Rieman tangential space characteristics are extracted. We validated the performance of the proposed approach in the RT estimation from EEG signals measured in a large-scale PVT experiment, and showed that tangential space characteristics can reduce the RMSE estimate by 4.30-8.30% and increase the CC estimate by 6.59-11.13% compared to traditional powerband characteristics. To our knowledge, this is the first time that RG is used in BCI regression problems. Our future research will focus on reducing the dimensionality of tangential space characteristics and increasing the CC estimate by 6.59-11.13%. metadata.abstractText: Riemannian geometry has been successfully used in many brain-computer interface (BCI) classification problems and demonstrated superior performance. In this paper, for the first time, it is applied to BCI regression problems, an important category of BCI applications. More specifically, we propose a new feature extraction approach for Electroencephalogram (EEG) based BCI regression problems: a spatial filter is first used to increase the signal quality of the EEG trials and also to reduce the dimensionality of the covariance matrices, and then Riemannian tangent space features are extracted. We validate the performance of the proposed approach in reaction time estimation from EEG signals measured in a large-scale sustained-attention psychomotor vigilance task, and show that compared with the traditional powerband features, the tangent space features can reduce the root mean square estimation error by 4.30-8.30%, and increase the estimation correlation coefficient by 6.59-11.13%.
